ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: High resolution photolithography with sub-wavelength grating

Affiliation.OrgName: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Lab of Optical Technologies on Nano-fabrication and Micro-engineering, Institute of Optical and Electronics

Affiliation.OrgName: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Based on the theory of surface plasmon resonance and the special nano-optical effect of metal/dielectric multilayer composites, we obtained a high-resolution image of a sub-wavelength grating. We discussed multilayer parameters on equal thickness, and achieved sufficient contrast and high intensity through numerical simulation based on the finite element method. By chosen the best scheme, an experimental of multilayer planar lens lithography has been carried out. The main point is the use of metal–dielectric composites to realize high-resolution image under 365-nm polarization light incidence. By controlling the experimental parameters accurately, a fidelity image is recorded on the photoresist.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Due to the loss of information carried by evanescent frequency components of the optical field, the resolution of any conventional microscope is limited to approximately half of the incidence wavelength [1]. As a new method to break-through the diffraction limitation, a metal slice called “superlens” has received much attention [2]. Under the illuminating of transverse magnetic (TM) waves, the surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) excited on the metal surface can amplify and compensate the decaying of evanescent waves and transmit it to the image plane as propagating waves, then realizing perfect imaging beyond diffraction limitation [3, 4]. The distance between object plane and image plane is further increased by metal/dielectric multi-layers [5]. It is an extremely attractive application to utilize SPPs for nanolithography. The traditional ways, such as decreasing incidence wavelength and raising numerical aperture, hardly utilize evanescent waves to improve photolithography resolution. Nanolithography based on SPPs can transmit full-wave spectrum of object and obtain higher resolution pattern at photoresist (Pr) layer [6–8]. Several groups of researchers further extended the photolithography structure soon afterwards and validated it in both theory and experiment [9–12]. Although its working range is confined in the near field, it has truly realized super-resolution in a new way. So the SPPs nanolithography will have potential advantage in many science research fields.

In this paper, we proposed a new high-resolution structure composed of Ag/SiO2 multi-layers. Theoretical analysis indicates that it can transmit higher frequency evanescent components efficiently. Numerical simulation demonstrates the validity for transmitting the sub-wavelength pattern feature to the image plane. An experimental was carried out to prove this whole theory.

Section2.Heading: Principle of design
Section2.Para: The SPP is an electronic oscillation induced by incident electromagnetic waves at the surface of metal slab, which can amplify and compensate the decaying of evanescent waves and transmit it to the image plane as propagating waves, then realizing perfect imaging beyond diffraction limitation. By simplifying certification, it is found that a satisfactory image can be obtained with illuminated TM waves, when the incidence direction is perpendicular to the interface between metal and dielectric [2].

In an anisotropic medium employed by superlens, the high frequency components of the Fourier spectrum can be used effectively. SPPs on the metal surface can be excited to couple with decaying evanescent waves, so the fine character information beyond diffraction limit can be transmitted. Here, we chose Ag/SiO2 multilayer as the anisotropic material, and Cr as the mask material. The cross section of the proposed structure is shown in Fig. 1. According to the Drude model theory, we can calculate the permittivity ε of metal by
$\varepsilon (\omega ) = \varepsilon_{0} - \omega_{p}^{2}/[\omega (\omega + iV_{c})]$ . For Cr, ε 0=3.2, ω
p =2.2×1016 rad/s, V
c =3.8×1015 rad/s, then ε Cr=−8.5734+8.6632∗i; for Ag, ε 0=4.2, ω
p =1.3×1016 rad/s, V
c =9.1×1013 rad/s, then ε Ag=−2.4012+0.2488∗i. In addition,
$\varepsilon_{\mathrm{SiO}_{2}} = 2.13$ , permittivity of both the metal and dielectric will to be proximate, which is beneficial for transmitting evanescent waves. By considering the loss coefficient and convenient fabrication, we set the entire thickness of alternated Ag/SiO2 films as 60 nm, while each film is 10-nm thick (3 pairs of Ag/SiO2 films). The 40-nm thick Cr mask is deposited on the quartz glass, with a 230-nm period and 100-nm slot. According to the effective medium theory, ε
x =f⋅ε
d +(1−f)ε
m , ε
z =ε
m ⋅ε
d /[f⋅ε
m +(1−f)ε
d ], where f is the filling ratio of the metal, ε
d and ε
m are respectively the permittivities of dielectric and metal. According to the dispersion relationship,
$k_{x}^{2}/\varepsilon_{z} + k_{z}^{2}/\varepsilon_{x} = k_{0}^{2}$ , the flatter dispersion relationship makes it possible to effectively transmit the sub-wavelength information [13]. Then ε
x <0 and ε
z >0 can be easily achieved for more transmission of high frequency components at the 365-nm working wavelength with f=0.5. In addition, the Cr mask is planarized by a 15-nm thick polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) layer, with ε PMMA=2.4. The image pattern is recorded by photoresist with the thickness of 50 nm, with ε pr=2.56.
Fig. 1
Schematic of the designed structure

The optical transfer function (OTF) of the proposed Ag/SiO2 multilayer films is shown in Fig. 2. The three lines express different results corresponding to different conditions. The solid line is illuminated by TM waves, which have a magnetic field component parallel to the plane of objects. The dashed line is illuminated by TE waves, which have an electric field component parallel to the plane of objects. The dotted line is illuminated by TM waves, but the Ag/SiO2 layers are replaced by PMMA. It can be seen that the transmission is not widely varied in low frequency, the solid and dashed lines superimpose and are lower than the dotted line because of metal loss. But the solid line reflects better than the others the conditions obviously in high frequency, especially from 1.5k0 to 3k0. It is due to the incident waves induced the SPPs on the Ag surface, which amplified and compensated the decaying of high frequency components. So there are more messages transmitted through the multi-layers. It also demonstrates that the designed structure can transmit evanescent waves to photoresist layer based on SPPs.
Fig. 2
OTF for the designed structure

To illustrate the validity of our methodology, we further carried out the simulation of the designed structure based on the finite element method. The 365-nm TM-polarized waves illuminate from the bottom and perpendicularly to the plane of objects. The both side edges are a the matched boundary condition, the top and bottom edges are the scattering boundary condition. The image of sub-wavelength grating is gathered at the plane 30 nm below the photoresist surface. The electric field intensity distribution is shown in Figs. 3 and 4. We use light intensity (I) and contrast (C) to demonstrate the result. The contrast can be expressed as
$$\begin{aligned} C =& (I_{\max} - I_{\min} ) / (I_{\max} + I_{\min} ) \\ =& \bigl(E_{\max}^{2} - E_{\min}^{2}\bigr)/ \bigl(E_{\max}^{2} + E_{\min}^{2}\bigr) \end{aligned}$$ The simulated contrast of grating image is 0.87, while the field intensity distributes uniformly, which is sufficient to explain the characteristic of high-resolution imaging.
Fig. 3
Schematics of electric field intensity distribution for the proposed configuration
Fig. 4
Cross-sectional intensity distribution at the plane 30 nm below the photoresist surface. The thick red curve shows the Ag/SiO2 multi-layers, the dotted black curve the PMMA layer, and the thin blue curve the objects

For a qualitative comparison, we theoretically computed the resolving power of different materials. The results are shown in Fig. 4. The light transmits through Ag/SiO2 multi-layers, PMMA layer, respectively. The data are all collected at a depth of 30 nm into the resist. The thick red curve shows Ag/SiO2 multi-layers, the dotted black curve shows PMMA layer, and the thin blue curve shows objects. Comparing the intensity distribution, we find that the 60-nm thick Ag/SiO2 multi-layers system has the best performance. Its intensity is higher than the others, and the full width at half maximum (FWHM) is 108 nm, slightly wider than the objects. If the composites are replaced by 60-nm thick PMMA, the intensity will decrease and the FWHM will broaden. So the Ag/SiO2 multi-layers structure has an improved pattern fidelity.

Section1.Heading: Experimental methods and results
Section1.Para: Based on actual conditions, we have the following process to obtain this high resolution structure. There are eight main processes: clearing the substrate, plating Cr film, coating glue, interfering lithography, ion beam etching (IBE), spinning PMMA, depositing multi-films, exposing and developing. Besides, these eight processes can be concluded as three stages: fabricating mask, metal–dielectric films deposition, and photolithography.

First, fabricate the Cr mask. We deposit Cr layer on quartz glass, then spin-coating the photoresist. We obtained the 100 nm feature pattern on the photoresist by self-built interference lithography system with 257-nm illumination [14, 15]. The pattern which has 100-nm width and 230-nm cycle can be obtained with high aspect ratio. Then the nanolithography mask was fabricated using an advanced IBE machine. This method can be used to transmit photoresist pattern to metal layer’s downside. By transferring the pattern to the Cr layer, the proper-sized mask is prepared readily for the near-field lithography experiment. The cross section of the mask is detected by atomic force microscopy (AFM), which is shown in Fig. 5.
Fig. 5
AFM picture of the mask surface after IBE process; the upper plot is its cross-sectional profile located at transverse line

Second, deposit the metal–dielectric multi-layers. Before deposition of alternate films, we need to use a kind of substance that could fill the gullies of the mask, for making the surface of mask smooth is essential for depositing multi-films on it later. Here we choose PMMA for two reasons. The first is that it has a better fluidity for filling the mask gullies, making the surface planar and then ensuring the multi-films on the PMMA plane. The second is that it has a better transmittance. By a strict control we can ensure that the PMMA has a proper thickness and keep a proper distance between multi-layers lens and exit face of the lattice. After several experiments and conclusions, we decided to repeat several times to ensure the filling of mask gullies, then the total thickness of PMMA would be far greater than the required thickness, which would result in reducing of evanescent wave before it reaches the multilayer lens, and no image would be formed. Therefore, we need to etch for a thin PMMA film. In this work, we can use reaction ion etching (RIE) and IBE. With proper parameter and controllable etching rate, the both methods are available. In this experiment, we chose RIE as it is much safer in order not to over-consume the mask. So it is available to obtain a planar surface of PMMA. We use AFM to scan the mask surface filled by the PMMA. The scanning area is 1 μm × 1 μm, which is shown in Fig. 6. We can see that the surface is rather smooth, and the roughness of RMS is about 0.5 nm, which meets the requirements of the experiment.
Fig. 6
AFM image of the PMMA surface morphology; the upper plot is its cross-sectional profile located at transverse line

Subsequently, magnetron sputtering method is used to deposition of Ag and SiO2 layers. Our experimental equipment can plate two kinds of material films at the same time. After comparing parameters for optimal allocation, we set the temperature of cavity the same as the room temperature. The gas flow rate of Ar is 80 sccm. When the cavity pressure is below 5.0 e-4 Pa, deposition of films can start. We chose direct current sputtering for Ag films. When the voltage is 440 V and the current is 0.3 A, it will get a 10-nm thick film in 12 seconds. The SiO2 films can be deposited by radio frequency sputtering. When the radio frequency power is 200 W, a 10-nm thick film will be obtained after 2 min. The multi-layers can be obtained by alternating deposition of 3 groups. The last surface layer is detected by AFM. The scanning area is 1 μm × 1 μm, and the roughness of RMS is about 1.6 nm, which is shown in Fig. 7.
Fig. 7
AFM image of the Ag/SiO2 composite surface morphology; the upper plot is its cross-sectional profile located at transverse line
From the detected results, we can see that the multi-layers are planar and uniform, and the RMS is about 1.6 nm, so it can be used to construct the high-resolution structure.

Third, the photoresist records the exposing massage. A suitable resist is chosen for a better examination. In practice, the light attenuates so fast that the energy may not suffice to sense the photoresist. In addition, the positive resist will be reserved after developing if it not sensed, while the negative resist will be reserved if it sensed. So the choice of a right resist will be more comfortable to record the light massages. Here, we chose the positive resist AR-3170, which is spin-coating 100 nm on other silicon substrates. In this experiment, a vacuum chuck is used to pull the mask onto the resist-coated substrate. The mask and the sample were held in close contact by applying pressure. We used 365-nm TM polarization light source illuminating, whose intensity is 2 mW/cm2. The lithography scanning electron microscopy (SEM) graph is shown in Fig. 8.
Fig. 8
SEM picture of corresponding resist pattern; in the inset a zoom-in image shows the grating period is quite uniform

We can see that the image period is 230 nm and slot width is 100 nm. The clear feature reproduces mask character successfully. The detected results show that the pattern is steady with high fidelity in several centimeters’ range, while the feature scale is uniform in multiplying factor pattern. The planar multilayer composites designed based on foregoing theory analysis and numerical simulation realized high-resolution photolithography. And the theory and the experiment have been mutually validated.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: We proposed a high resolution structure composed of Ag/SiO2 multi-layers. Theoretical analysis demonstrated this special anisotropic material which enables high-resolution plane photolithography to transmit fine feature messages. The simulation results verified that it projects pattern on planar surface from sub-wavelength mask. And the clear experimental results support our analysis. We believe that the super-resolution device based on SPP has a potential for photolithography, optical information storage and other relevant applications.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This work is supported by the International Cooperation Projects (No. 2011DFA63190) and National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 11275045, 11274058, 11004024, 61071027).
